PostValue.explanation: This is a short, informational consumer-post advertising charity-linked brands (Good.store, Who Gives a Crap, Newman’s Own). It’s plausibly useful for people looking for ethically-minded products or small donation channels, but it isn’t a substantive argument or a load-bearing claim for EA priorities, strategy, or cause-selection. If true or false it only modestly affects consumer donations/purchases rather than major policy or longtermist decisions, so its practical impact is limited (and there’s a small risk of encouraging purchase-instead-of-direct-donation behavior).

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Add verification and numbers for the charity claims. Readers will want to know what “all of the profits” and “more than $10M” actually mean in practice. Link to Good.store’s financials/Form 990s (or the charity partner receipts), clarify the time period for the $10M figure, and give a concrete example of what portion of a typical purchase ends up as a donation (e.g., $ sale price → $ profit → $ donated). If you can’t get those numbers, say so and flag the claim as unverified.

2) Address the obvious counterfactual/opportunity-cost objection: buying from a profit-for-good store vs donating directly to high-impact charities. Give readers a quick back-of-envelope comparison (or at least acknowledge the tradeoff): how much more (or less) of a purchase price ends up funding the charity compared to donating the same cash directly to a GiveWell-style charity. If you prefer purchases for non-impact reasons (convenience, product quality, supporting mission-driven businesses), state that explicitly.

3) Call out possible greenwashing and partner-effectiveness issues and add brief evidence. For environmental claims (e.g., 'concentrated = less resource waste'), either link to lifecycle or packaging info, or add a caveat that lifecycle impacts aren’t shown. For charity partners (Partners In Health, Coral Reef Alliance, etc.), link to a quick source on their effectiveness or note uncertainty. Also note the US-only scope up front as you did, but mention alternatives for non-US readers or invite others to add region-specific profit-for-good examples.
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: Targets real, important weaknesses for an EA audience: unverified money/‘all profits’ claims, lack of counterfactual (donate-directly) reasoning, and potential greenwashing/partner-effectiveness issues. Fixing these would substantially increase the post’s credibility without needing a huge rewrite. It isn’t catastrophic (the post is mainly a consumer tip), so it’s not a 9–10, but these are critical improvements that the author should address.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I can find no evidence that a "Dave Cortright 🔸" is a known figure in the EA/rationalist community—no high‑visibility posts, talks, or widely cited writings. The handle may be a pseudonym or minor online user. (There is an unrelated academic David Cortright in peace/arms‑control circles, but he is not prominent within EA.)

PostClarity.explanation: The post is clear and easy to follow: it states its purpose (to point readers toward Good.store and similar ‘profit for good’ brands), includes supporting quotes/links and a brief personal endorsement, and invites others to add suggestions. Weaknesses: it is mainly descriptive with little critical evaluation of impact or cost‑effectiveness, uses long quoted blocks that could be summarized for brevity, and the title mentions Hank & John Green while the body doesn’t explicitly name them, a minor mismatch.

PostNovelty.explanation: The post mainly shares examples of an existing model — consumer brands that donate profits (Good.store, Who Gives A Crap, Newman’s Own) — which is a well‑known concept among EA and longtermist communities. The only slightly novel element is surfacing a specific, newer actor (Good.store/Hank & John Green) and its fundraising figures, which is newsworthy but not a novel idea or claim.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: Strengths: The post clearly identifies and documents examples of companies that donate profits (Good.store, Who Gives a Crap, Newman’s Own), links to primary sources, and provides some personal anecdotal experience. Weaknesses: It is primarily promotional and anecdotal rather than analytical. It does not evaluate how much of revenue/profit is actually donated, lacks third‑party verification, does not assess charity effectiveness or cost‑effectiveness, and omits counterfactuals (would buying here increase overall donations vs. buying cheaper alternatives and donating directly?). The evidence is therefore thin and insufficient to strongly support a general claim that buying from these vendors is an effective way to give.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: Most empirical claims in the post are verifiable and well-supported by primary sources. Good.Store’s website explicitly states the charity partners, which product lines’ profits go to which partner (Awesome Socks & Sun Basin Soap → Partners In Health / Maternal Center of Excellence; Keats & Co → PIH TB work in Lesotho; EcoGeek → Coral Reef Alliance / Maui Watershed Restoration) and states total donations on site (pages show wording around >$9M–$10M). Partners In Health and Coral Reef Alliance pages confirm the described projects (MCOE in Sierra Leone; PIH TB programs in Lesotho; CORAL’s Olowalu/Maui watershed work). Who Gives A Crap and Newman’s Own claims are supported by their own sites. Main caveats: (1) the exact cumulative donation figure is a Good.Store self-report and site pages show slightly different numbers (e.g., “more than $9M” on some product pages vs “more than $10M” on the About page); (2) the phrase “Tuberculosis is the world's deadliest disease” is imprecise — WHO reported TB reclaimed the status of the leading infectious-disease killer in 2023 (so the claim is true for infectious diseases as of 2023/2024, but inaccurate if read as “world’s deadliest disease” without the infectious-disease qualifier); and (3) most donation totals and program details are reported by the involved organisations themselves (Good.Store, PIH, CORAL), so independent audit documents or a public donation ledger would further strengthen verification.
